doc.abstracts: On November 19, 2007, Geoffrey B. Lamb was interviewed on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by William H. Becker. During his tenure at the Bank from 1980 to 2006, Mr. Lamb worked in the following areas: in the development research center as an economist (1980-1982); in the project policy department as an institutional development specialist (1982-1983) and as an advisor to the public sector management (1983-1987); in the strategic planning and review department as an advisor (1987-1991); in the Europe and Central Asia (ECA), Middle East and North Africa (MNA) technical department as unit chief (1991-1993) and as manager (1993-1994); in the external affairs department as a resident representative to the United Kingdom and Ireland (1994-1997) and as senior advisor (1997); in the trust funds and co-financing department as director (1997-2003); and as vice president for both the resource mobilization and co-financing department (2003) and the concessional finance and global partnerships (2003-2006). Growing up in South Africa, he was involved in the underground anti-apartheid movement and was in prison and then in political exile in the U.K. His transcript concerns his work on the World Development Report (WDR), at necessity of the International Development Association (IDA), business with the Bill Gates Foundation, and the relationship between the donors of the World Bank and trust funds under the auspices of Ernie Stern.
